The man that had a-holt of me was very good to me, and kept saying he had a boy about as big as me that died last year, and he was sorry to see a boy in such a dangerous fix; and when they was all took by surprise by finding the gold, and made a rush for the coffin, he lets go of me and whispers, ‘Heel it now, or they’ll hang ye, sure!’ and I lit out. It didn’t seem no good for me to stay—I couldn’t do nothing, and I didn’t want to be hung if I could get away. So I never stopped running till I found the canoe; and when I got here I told Jim to hurry, or they’d catch me and hang me yet, and said I was afeard you and the duke wasn’t alive now, and I was awful sorry, and so was Jim, and was awful glad when we see you coming; you may ask Jim if I didn’t.”
Jim said it was so; and the king told him to shut up, and said, “Oh, yes, it’s mighty likely!” and shook me up again, and said he reckoned he’d drownd me. But the duke says:
“Leggo the boy, you old idiot! Would you a done any different? Did you inquire around for him when you got loose? I don’t remember it.”

events.title: The Duke's Rebuke and Mounting Accusations
detailed_summary: After letting Huck go, the King begins to curse the town and its inhabitants.
The Duke sharply corrects the King, asserting that the King himself is the one most deserving of blame due to his consistently foolish actions.

The Duke concedes that the King's 'imaginary blue-arrow mark' trick was a clever move that saved them from being jailed until the Englishmen's baggage arrived, which would have led to the penitentiary.
He emphasizes that this trick led them to the graveyard, and the subsequent chaos over the gold was an even greater stroke of luck, as the crowd's distraction prevented them from being lynched.
Following a brief silence, the King muses aloud that they had believed the slaves were responsible for stealing the gold, a comment that visibly disturbs Huck.
The Duke responds with slow, deliberate sarcasm, affirming their prior, mistaken belief.
The King then attempts to claim he was the one who specifically thought the slaves stole it, leading to a contentious exchange with the Duke, who insists he was the one with that thought.
Their argument intensifies as they question each other's references, culminating in the Duke pointedly asking the King if he doesn't already know who actually hid the money in the coffin.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So the king let go of me, and begun to cuss that town and everybody in it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Don’t you reckon I know who hid that money in that coffin?”

events.text_segment:
So the king let go of me, and begun to cuss that town and everybody in it. But the duke says:
“You better a blame sight give yourself a good cussing, for you’re the one that’s entitled to it most. You hain’t done a thing from the start that had any sense in it, except coming out so cool and cheeky with that imaginary blue-arrow mark. That was bright—it was right down bully; and it was the thing that saved us. For if it hadn’t been for that, they’d a jailed us till them Englishmen’s baggage come—and then—the penitentiary, you bet! But that trick took ’em to the graveyard, and the gold done us a still bigger kindness; for if the excited fools hadn’t let go all holts and made that rush to get a look, we’d a slept in our cravats to-night—cravats warranted to wear, too—longer than we’d need ’em.”
They was still a minute—thinking; then the king says, kind of absent-minded like:
“Mf! And we reckoned the niggers stole it!”
That made me squirm!
“Yes,” says the duke, kinder slow and deliberate and sarcastic, “We did.”
After about a half a minute the king drawls out:
“Leastways, I did.”
The duke says, the same way:
“On the contrary, I did.”
The king kind of ruffles up, and says:
“Looky here, Bilgewater, what’r you referrin’ to?”
The duke says, pretty brisk:
“When it comes to that, maybe you’ll let me ask, what was you referring to?”
“Shucks!” says the king, very sarcastic; “but I don’t know—maybe you was asleep, and didn’t know what you was about.”
The duke bristles up now, and says:
“Oh, let up on this cussed nonsense; do you take me for a blame’ fool? Don’t you reckon I know who hid that money in that coffin?”

If it hadn't been for that, they would have been jailed until the real English brothers arrived, which would have certainly meant prison. But that trick directed attention to the graveyard, and finding the gold was even more beneficial; if the excited crowd hadn't lost all control and rushed to look, they would have been hanged that night, with ropes that would last longer than their lives. They fell silent for a minute, lost in thought. Then the king, somewhat distractedly, murmured, 'Huh! And we believed the slaves stole it!' That remark made me uneasy. 'Yes,' the duke replied, slowly, deliberately, and sarcastically, 'We did.' After another brief pause, the king drawled, 'At least, *I* did.' events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
The king let go of me and started to curse the whole town and everyone in it. But the duke interrupted, saying, "You really should be cursing yourself, since you deserve it most. From the beginning, nothing you've done has made any sense except acting so confident about that made-up blue-arrow mark. That was clever—it really saved us. If not for that trick, they would have locked us up until the Englishmen’s baggage arrived, and then—straight to prison for us! The duke replied in the same tone, "On the contrary, I did."

The king, getting defensive, said, "Hold on there, Bilgewater, what do you mean by that?"

The duke quickly shot back, "Maybe I should be asking what you meant."

"Nonsense!" the king replied sarcastically. "Maybe you were asleep and didn’t know what was happening."

The duke, now getting annoyed, said, "Oh, quit this foolishness; do you take me for an idiot? Don’t you think I know who hid that money in the coffin?"

events.title: The King's Forced Confession and Drunken Reconciliation
detailed_summary: The Duke directly accuses the King of having hidden the money in the coffin himself.
The King vehemently denies this, prompting the Duke to physically assault him by grabbing his throat.
Under duress, the King quickly retracts his denial.
The Duke then forces the King to confess that he hid the money with the intention of deceiving the Duke later, returning to retrieve it, and keeping it all for himself.
The King attempts to deflect by asking the Duke if he hadn't also considered hiding the money.
The Duke admits the thought had crossed his mind but states he didn't act on it, contrasting this with the King, whom he insists both thought of it and did it.
The King makes one last, desperate denial but, as the Duke continues to choke him, finally gasps out a confession.
Huck expresses his immense relief upon hearing the King's admission.

The Duke releases the King, warning him against ever denying it again, and then launches into a tirade, berating the King for his insatiable greed, for allowing innocent slaves to be blamed, and for his deceitful behavior.
The King meekly attempts to shift blame regarding a previous financial discrepancy, but the Duke dismisses him.
The Duke concludes by pointing out that their actions have led to them losing all the stolen money and most of their own funds.
The King retreats to the wigwam and begins drinking, soon joined by the Duke.
Within about half an hour, both are heavily intoxicated, becoming affectionately close and eventually falling asleep arm-in-arm.
Huck observes that, despite his drunkenness, the King seems to remember not to deny his confession about the money bag, which makes Huck feel secure.
Once the two conmen are snoring, Huck recounts all these events to Jim.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Yes, sir! I know you do know, because you done it yourself!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Of course when they got to snoring we had a long gabble, and I told Jim everything.

events.text_segment:
“Yes, sir! I know you do know, because you done it yourself!”
“It’s a lie!”—and the duke went for him. The king sings out:
“Take y’r hands off!—leggo my throat!—I take it all back!”
The duke says:
“Well, you just own up, first, that you did hide that money there, intending to give me the slip one of these days, and come back and dig it up, and have it all to yourself.”
“Wait jest a minute, duke—answer me this one question, honest and fair; if you didn’t put the money there, say it, and I’ll b’lieve you, and take back everything I said.”
“You old scoundrel, I didn’t, and you know I didn’t. There, now!”
“Well, then, I b’lieve you. But answer me only jest this one more—now don’t git mad; didn’t you have it in your mind to hook the money and hide it?”
The duke never said nothing for a little bit; then he says:
“Well, I don’t care if I did, I didn’t do it, anyway. But you not only had it in mind to do it, but you done it.”
“I wisht I never die if I done it, duke, and that’s honest. I won’t say I warn’t goin’ to do it, because I was; but you—I mean somebody—got in ahead o’ me.”
“It’s a lie! You done it, and you got to say you done it, or—”
The king began to gurgle, and then he gasps out:
“’Nough!—I own up!”
I was very glad to hear him say that; it made me feel much more easier than what I was feeling before. So the duke took his hands off and says:
“If you ever deny it again I’ll drown you. It’s well for you to set there and blubber like a baby—it’s fitten for you, after the way you’ve acted. I never see such an old ostrich for wanting to gobble everything—and I a-trusting you all the time, like you was my own father. You ought to been ashamed of yourself to stand by and hear it saddled on to a lot of poor niggers, and you never say a word for ’em. It makes me feel ridiculous to think I was soft enough to believe that rubbage. Cuss you, I can see now why you was so anxious to make up the deffisit—you wanted to get what money I’d got out of the Nonesuch and one thing or another, and scoop it all!”
The king says, timid, and still a-snuffling:
“Why, duke, it was you that said make up the deffisit; it warn’t me.”
“Dry up! I don’t want to hear no more out of you!” says the duke. “And now you see what you got by it. They’ve got all their own money back, and all of ourn but a shekel or two besides. G’long to bed, and don’t you deffersit me no more deffersits, long ’s you live!”
So the king sneaked into the wigwam and took to his bottle for comfort, and before long the duke tackled his bottle; and so in about a half an hour they was as thick as thieves again, and the tighter they got, the lovinger they got, and went off a-snoring in each other’s arms. They both got powerful mellow, but I noticed the king didn’t get mellow enough to forget to remember to not deny about hiding the money-bag again. That made me feel easy and satisfied. Of course when they got to snoring we had a long gabble, and I told Jim everything.

Let go of my throat! They both got very drunk, but I noticed the King didn’t get drunk enough to forget to remember *not* to deny hiding the money bag again. That made me feel calm and satisfied. Of course, once they were snoring, Jim and I had a long talk, and I told him everything.

"You old rascal, I didn't hide it, and you know it. There you have it!"

events.title: The Con Artists' Failing Schemes and Desperation
detailed_summary: The group travels further south, avoiding towns for an extended period as they journey down the river.
They arrive in a warmer climate, where Huck encounters Spanish moss for the first time, finding its appearance made the woods seem solemn and dismal.
Believing they are no longer in danger, the duke and king resume their attempts to swindle people in villages.
Their temperance lecture fails to generate enough money for them to even get drunk.
An attempt to start a dancing school also fails due to their utter lack of dancing ability, resulting in the public chasing them out of town.
Their efforts at elocution are similarly unsuccessful, with the audience verbally abusing them and forcing their departure.
They try various other cons, including missionary work, mesmerism, doctoring, and fortune-telling, but none bring them any luck.
Consequently, they end up completely broke and dejected, spending their days idly on the raft, lost in thought and despair as they float along.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We dasn’t stop again at any town for days and days; kept right along down the river.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So at last they got just about dead broke, and laid around the raft as she floated along, thinking and thinking, and never saying nothing, by the half a day at a time, and dreadful blue and desperate.

events.text_segment:
We dasn’t stop again at any town for days and days; kept right along down the river. We was down south in the warm weather now, and a mighty long ways from home. We begun to come to trees with Spanish moss on them, hanging down from the limbs like long, gray beards. It was the first I ever see it growing, and it made the woods look solemn and dismal. So now the frauds reckoned they was out of danger, and they begun to work the villages again.
First they done a lecture on temperance; but they didn’t make enough for them both to get drunk on. Then in another village they started a dancing-school; but they didn’t know no more how to dance than a kangaroo does; so the first prance they made the general public jumped in and pranced them out of town. Another time they tried to go at yellocution; but they didn’t yellocute long till the audience got up and give them a solid good cussing, and made them skip out. They tackled missionarying, and mesmerizing, and doctoring, and telling fortunes, and a little of everything; but they couldn’t seem to have no luck. So at last they got just about dead broke, and laid around the raft as she floated along, thinking and thinking, and never saying nothing, by the half a day at a time, and dreadful blue and desperate.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: For several days, we were forced to avoid stopping at any towns and continued floating down the river without pause. We had traveled far south into the warm region by now, a very long distance from our starting point. We began encountering trees adorned with Spanish moss, which hung from the branches resembling long, gray beards. I had never seen this before, and it gave the forest a serious and gloomy look. Convinced they were no longer in peril, the swindlers decided to resume their trickery in the nearby villages. First, they attempted a lecture promoting abstinence from alcohol, but the earnings weren't even sufficient for both of them to afford drinks. Next, in another village, they established a dancing school; however, they were utterly incapable dancers, perhaps worse than a kangaroo. As soon as they tried to perform a step, the local people became enraged and drove them out of town by dancing them away. On another occasion, they tried a performance called "yellocution," but the audience quickly grew hostile, gave them a severe scolding with curses, and made them leave in a hurry. They also tried working as missionaries, hypnotists, doctors, fortune-tellers, and engaged in various other attempts, but they seemed to have no success at all. Eventually, they found themselves completely broke and spent their time lying on the raft as it drifted, deeply lost in thought for hours on end, saying nothing, and appearing terribly dejected and without hope.

Now we were down south, where the weather was warm, and we were far from where we started. We started seeing trees covered in Spanish moss, hanging from the branches like long, gray beards. I had never seen it growing before, and it made the woods appear gloomy and eerie. The con men figured they were safe now, so they started scamming people in the villages again. events.title: Ominous Plotting and the King's Reconnaissance
detailed_summary: The duke and king shift their behavior, beginning to hold long, secretive discussions in the wigwam.
This change makes Huck and Jim uneasy, as they suspect the con men are concocting a more serious and wicked scheme than ever before.
Huck and Jim speculate that the frauds might be planning a burglary, counterfeit money operation, or some other nefarious activity.
Concerned, they agree that if the duke and king attempt any such wrongdoing, they will immediately abandon them.
Early one morning, they conceal the raft near Pikesville, a small and shabby village.
The king decides to go ashore alone, instructing Huck, Jim, and the duke to stay hidden while he investigates whether word of the 'Royal Nonesuch' scam has reached the town.
Huck privately believes the king is actually going to rob a house and anticipates that he, Jim, and the raft will be gone when the king returns, leaving the king to wonder about their disappearance.
The king sets a condition: if he doesn't return by midday, it means the coast is clear, and the duke and Huck should join him in town.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And at last they took a change and begun to lay their heads together in the wigwam and talk low and confidential two or three hours at a time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And he said if he warn’t back by midday the duke and me would know it was all right, and we was to come along.

events.text_segment: And at last they took a change and begun to lay their heads together in the wigwam and talk low and confidential two or three hours at a time. Jim and me got uneasy. We didn’t like the look of it. We judged they was studying up some kind of worse deviltry than ever. We turned it over and over, and at last we made up our minds they was going to break into somebody’s house or store, or was going into the counterfeit-money business, or something. So then we was pretty scared, and made up an agreement that we wouldn’t have nothing in the world to do with such actions, and if we ever got the least show we would give them the cold shake and clear out and leave them behind. Well, early one morning we hid the raft in a good, safe place about two mile below a little bit of a shabby village named Pikesville, and the king he went ashore and told us all to stay hid whilst he went up to town and smelt around to see if anybody had got any wind of the Royal Nonesuch there yet. (“House to rob, you mean,” says I to myself; “and when you get through robbing it you’ll come back here and wonder what has become of me and Jim and the raft—and you’ll have to take it out in wondering.”) And he said if he warn’t back by midday the duke and me would know it was all right, and we was to come along.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: The King and the Duke started spending hours whispering together privately in their tent, which made Jim and me uneasy because we suspected they were planning something even more wicked than usual. After much thought, we guessed they were going to rob a house or store, or perhaps get into the counterfeit money business. This frightened us quite a bit, so we made a pact that we would have absolutely nothing to do with such actions and would leave them behind at the first opportunity. One morning, we hid the raft securely about two miles downstream from a small, run-down village called Pikesville. The King went ashore, telling us to stay hidden while he went into town to see if anyone there had heard about the Royal Nonesuch. (I figured to myself, "He means a house to rob, and when he's finished, he'll come back, wonder what happened to Jim, me, and the raft, and that's all the worrying he'll do.") He said that if he didn't return by midday, the Duke and I should assume everything was clear and come to town.

events.title: A Fleeting Chance for Freedom and Jim's Shocking Absence
detailed_summary: Huck and the duke remain at the raft, awaiting news from the king.
The duke grows increasingly anxious and irritable, finding fault with everything and creating a tense atmosphere.
Huck senses that trouble is imminent but feels a sense of relief when midday passes without the king's return, hoping this might bring a change or an opportunity for them.
Huck and the duke then proceed to the village to locate the king.
They find him in the back room of a disreputable tavern, extremely intoxicated, while a group of loafers harasses him for amusement.
The king, too drunk to stand or defend himself effectively, responds with curses and threats.
The duke begins to scold the king for his foolish behavior, and the king retorts angrily.
Recognizing a perfect opportunity as the two con men argue, Huck quickly flees, running towards the river with the intention of escaping with Jim on the raft.
Overjoyed at the prospect of freedom, Huck calls out to Jim to set the raft loose.
However, there is no response from the wigwam, and Huck discovers that Jim is gone.
Huck frantically searches the nearby woods, shouting and calling for Jim, but his efforts are futile; Jim has vanished.
Overcome with distress and the sudden loss, Huck sits down and begins to weep.

events.text_segment:
So we stayed where we was. The duke he fretted and sweated around, and was in a mighty sour way. He scolded us for everything, and we couldn’t seem to do nothing right; he found fault with every little thing. Something was a-brewing, sure. I was good and glad when midday come and no king; we could have a change, anyway—and maybe a chance for the change on top of it. So me and the duke went up to the village, and hunted around there for the king, and by-and-by we found him in the back room of a little low doggery, very tight, and a lot of loafers bullyragging him for sport, and he a-cussing and a-threatening with all his might, and so tight he couldn’t walk, and couldn’t do nothing to them. The duke he begun to abuse him for an old fool, and the king begun to sass back, and the minute they was fairly at it I lit out and shook the reefs out of my hind legs, and spun down the river road like a deer, for I see our chance; and I made up my mind that it would be a long day before they ever see me and Jim again. I got down there all out of breath but loaded up with joy, and sung out:
“Set her loose, Jim! we’re all right now!”
But there warn’t no answer, and nobody come out of the wigwam. Jim was gone! I set up a shout—and then another—and then another one; and run this way and that in the woods, whooping and screeching; but it warn’t no use—old Jim was gone. Then I set down and cried; I couldn’t help it.

events.title: Learning of Jim's Capture and the Forty-Dollar Betrayal
detailed_summary: Too agitated to remain seated, Huck soon goes out to the road, trying to figure out his next move.
He encounters a boy walking along and asks if he has seen a Black man fitting Jim's description.
The boy confirms he saw such a man at Silas Phelps's farm, about two miles away, adding that the man is a captured runaway slave.
Huck, feigning alarm, concocts a story about being threatened by the Black man in the woods earlier, explaining his supposed fear and disinterest in the man's whereabouts.
The boy reassures Huck that he no longer needs to be afraid because the runaway has been caught, and mentions that the man apparently fled from somewhere further south.
Huck pretends to be pleased that the runaway has been apprehended.
The boy then reveals that there is a two-hundred-dollar reward for the captured man.
Maintaining his pretense, Huck laments that he could have claimed the reward himself if he were older, as he claims to have seen the man first.
The boy clarifies that an old stranger captured Jim and sold his claim on the reward for forty dollars because the stranger was in a hurry to go upriver and couldn't wait.
The boy attests to the legitimacy of the capture, stating he personally saw the handbill which described Jim perfectly, including the plantation he was from near New Orleans.
After sharing this information, the boy asks Huck for some chewing tobacco, which Huck does not have, and then the boy departs.

events.text_segment:
But I couldn’t set still long. Pretty soon I went out on the road, trying to think what I better do, and I run across a boy walking, and asked him if he’d seen a strange nigger dressed so and so, and he says:
“Yes.”
“Whereabouts?” says I.
“Down to Silas Phelps’ place, two mile below here. He’s a runaway nigger, and they’ve got him. Was you looking for him?”
“You bet I ain’t! I run across him in the woods about an hour or two ago, and he said if I hollered he’d cut my livers out—and told me to lay down and stay where I was; and I done it. Been there ever since; afeard to come out.”
“Well,” he says, “you needn’t be afeard no more, becuz they’ve got him. He run off f’m down South, som’ers.”
“It’s a good job they got him.”
“Well, I reckon! There’s two hunderd dollars reward on him. It’s like picking up money out’n the road.”
“Yes, it is—and I could a had it if I’d been big enough; I see him first. Who nailed him?”
“It was an old fellow—a stranger—and he sold out his chance in him for forty dollars, becuz he’s got to go up the river and can’t wait. Think o’ that, now! You bet I’d wait, if it was seven year.”
“That’s me, every time,” says I. “But maybe his chance ain’t worth no more than that, if he’ll sell it so cheap. Maybe there’s something ain’t straight about it.”
“But it is, though—straight as a string. I see the handbill myself. It tells all about him, to a dot—paints him like a picture, and tells the plantation he’s frum, below Newrleans. No-sirree-bob, they ain’t no trouble ’bout that speculation, you bet you. Say, gimme a chaw tobacker, won’t ye?”

events.title: Huck's Agonizing Moral Conflict and the Letter of Betrayal
detailed_summary: After the boy leaves, Huck returns to the raft and sits in the wigwam, deep in thought but unable to find a way out of his predicament.

He is devastated by the realization that their entire journey and all their sacrifices have come to naught, all because the con men could betray Jim for a mere forty dollars, condemning him to a life of slavery among strangers.
He briefly entertains the idea that Jim might be better off as a slave back home with his family and considers writing to Tom Sawyer to inform Miss Watson of Jim's location.

However, he quickly abandons this notion, fearing Miss Watson's anger would lead her to sell Jim further down the river, or, if she didn't, Jim would constantly suffer the stigma of being an 'ungrateful' runaway.
Huck then considers the social repercussions for himself: if word got out that he had helped a slave escape, he would face immense shame and ostracism.
He feels trapped by his past actions and the prevailing societal views, recognizing the desire to hide wrongdoing to avoid disgrace.
His conscience plagues him relentlessly, making him feel increasingly wicked and morally debased.

He comes to view Jim's capture as a divine intervention, a sign from Providence punishing him for the sin of aiding a runaway slave, whom he refers to as 'a poor old woman’s nigger' who had done him no harm.

He attempts to mitigate his guilt by blaming his 'wicked' upbringing, but an inner voice reminds him that he had the option of attending Sunday school, where he would have learned that his actions concerning Jim lead to eternal damnation.

events.text_segment:
I didn’t have none, so he left. I went to the raft, and set down in the wigwam to think. But I couldn’t come to nothing. I thought till I wore my head sore, but I couldn’t see no way out of the trouble. After all this long journey, and after all we’d done for them scoundrels, here it was all come to nothing, everything all busted up and ruined, because they could have the heart to serve Jim such a trick as that, and make him a slave again all his life, and amongst strangers, too, for forty dirty dollars.
Once I said to myself it would be a thousand times better for Jim to be a slave at home where his family was, as long as he’d got to be a slave, and so I’d better write a letter to Tom Sawyer and tell him to tell Miss Watson where he was. But I soon give up that notion for two things: she’d be mad and disgusted at his rascality and ungratefulness for leaving her, and so she’d sell him straight down the river again; and if she didn’t, everybody naturally despises an ungrateful nigger, and they’d make Jim feel it all the time, and so he’d feel ornery and disgraced. And then think of me! It would get all around that Huck Finn helped a nigger to get his freedom; and if I was ever to see anybody from that town again I’d be ready to get down and lick his boots for shame. That’s just the way: a person does a low-down thing, and then he don’t want to take no consequences of it. Thinks as long as he can hide it, it ain’t no disgrace. That was my fix exactly. The more I studied about this, the more my conscience went to grinding me, and the more wicked and low-down and ornery I got to feeling. And at last, when it hit me all of a sudden that here was the plain hand of Providence slapping me in the face and letting me know my wickedness was being watched all the time from up there in heaven, whilst I was stealing a poor old woman’s nigger that hadn’t ever done me no harm, and now was showing me there’s One that’s always on the lookout, and ain’t a-going to allow no such miserable doings to go only just so fur and no further, I most dropped in my tracks I was so scared. Well, I tried the best I could to kinder soften it up somehow for myself by saying I was brung up wicked, and so I warn’t so much to blame; but something inside of me kept saying, “There was the Sunday-school, you could a gone to it; and if you’d a done it they’d a learnt you there that people that acts as I’d been acting about that nigger goes to everlasting fire.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Since I had no money, the person left. I returned to the raft and sat inside the shelter to think things over. But I couldn't arrive at any conclusion. I thought until my head ached, but I couldn't find any way out of the predicament. After this entire long journey, and after everything we had done for those deceitful men, it had all amounted to nothing; everything was ruined and destroyed because they had the cruelty to play such a trick on Jim, sending him back into lifelong slavery, and among strangers, for a mere forty dollars. At one point, I told myself it would be infinitely better for Jim to be enslaved back home where his family was, if he absolutely had to be a slave, and therefore I should write to Tom Sawyer and ask him to inform Miss Watson where Jim was. But I quickly abandoned that idea for two reasons: she would be furious and disgusted by his perceived wickedness and ingratitude for running away, and would immediately sell him further down the river; and even if she didn't, everyone naturally looks down on an ungrateful enslaved person, and they would constantly make Jim feel it, causing him to feel miserable and dishonored. And then consider my own situation! It would become widely known that Huck Finn assisted an enslaved person in gaining freedom; and if I ever encountered anyone from that town again, I would feel so ashamed I'd be ready to humble myself completely. That's how it is: someone does something despicable and then wants to avoid the consequences. They think that as long as they can hide it, it isn't truly shameful. That was exactly my dilemma. The more I thought about this, the more my conscience bothered me, and the more wicked, contemptible, and low I felt. And finally, when it suddenly hit me that this was clearly the hand of divine power confronting me and showing me that my sin was being watched constantly from heaven while I was helping a poor old woman's enslaved person escape, someone who had never harmed me, and now showing me there is a presence that is always watching and will not allow such terrible actions to go beyond a certain point, I nearly collapsed where I stood I was so terrified. Well, I tried my best to somehow lessen the blow for myself by saying I was raised badly, and so I wasn't entirely to blame; but an inner voice kept saying, "There was Sunday school; you could have gone there. And if you had, they would have taught you that people who act as you have concerning that enslaved person are destined for eternal punishment."

events.title: The Power of Memory and Huck's Defining Choice for Jim
detailed_summary: The thought of eternal punishment makes Huck shiver, and he decides to pray in an attempt to reform himself and become a better person.
He kneels down, but the words of prayer elude him.

He understands that his inability to pray stems from a lack of sincerity; his heart isn't right because he's only pretending to renounce sin while still clinging to what society deems his greatest offense—helping Jim.
He realizes that one cannot offer a dishonest prayer.
Overwhelmed with trouble and uncertainty, he conceives an idea: he will write the letter to Miss Watson informing her of Jim's whereabouts, and then he will try to pray again.
Upon making this decision, he feels an immediate sense of relief, as if a great weight has been lifted.

Filled with gladness and excitement, he gets paper and a pencil and writes a concise note to Miss Watson, stating that her runaway slave Jim is at Mr. Phelps's place two miles below Pikesville and can be reclaimed for the reward.
He signs the letter 'HUCK FINN.'
For the first time in his life, he feels good and cleansed of sin, confident that he can now pray.
However, instead of praying immediately, he puts the letter down and reflects on how fortunate it was that events unfolded this way, considering how close he came to being 'lost and going to hell.'
His thoughts drift to his journey down the river with Jim, vividly recalling their shared moments day and night, in moonlight and storms, talking, singing, and laughing.

He finds no memories that harden his heart against Jim; instead, he remembers Jim's kindness: Jim taking Huck's watch so Huck could sleep, Jim's immense joy when Huck returned from the fog, and his relief when Huck rejoined him after the feud.
He recalls Jim's constant affection, calling him 'honey,' petting him, and doing everything he could for him, and how consistently good Jim had been.
He specifically remembers the time he saved Jim by lying about smallpox on the raft, and Jim's profound gratitude, calling Huck his best and only friend.
His gaze then falls upon the letter he just wrote.
He picks it up, trembling, fully aware that he faces an irrevocable choice between two paths.
After a moment of intense contemplation, holding his breath, he says to himself, 'All right, then, I’ll go to hell'—and tears up the letter.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It made me shiver.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: HUCK FINN.

events.text_segment:
It made me shiver. And I about made up my mind to pray, and see if I couldn’t try to quit being the kind of a boy I was and be better. So I kneeled down. But the words wouldn’t come. Why wouldn’t they? It warn’t no use to try and hide it from Him. Nor from me, neither. I knowed very well why they wouldn’t come. It was because my heart warn’t right; it was because I warn’t square; it was because I was playing double. I was letting on to give up sin, but away inside of me I was holding on to the biggest one of all. I was trying to make my mouth say I would do the right thing and the clean thing, and go and write to that nigger’s owner and tell where he was; but deep down in me I knowed it was a lie, and He knowed it. You can’t pray a lie—I found that out.
So I was full of trouble, full as I could be; and didn’t know what to do. At last I had an idea; and I says, I’ll go and write the letter—and then see if I can pray. Why, it was astonishing, the way I felt as light as a feather right straight off, and my troubles all gone. So I got a piece of paper and a pencil, all glad and excited, and set down and wrote:
Miss Watson, your runaway nigger Jim is down here two mile below Pikesville, and Mr. Phelps has got him and he will give him up for the reward if you send.
HUCK FINN.

I understood perfectly well why the words stayed stuck. It was because my intentions weren't sincere; it was because I wasn't being honest; I was being deceitful. I was pretending outwardly to renounce sin, but deep inside, I was clinging to the greatest sin of all. I was trying to make my mouth express the desire to do the right and honorable thing – to go and write to that enslaved man's owner and reveal his location; but deep within me, I knew it was a lie, and God knew it too. events.title: Embracing 'Wickedness': Huck's Plan to Free Jim Takes Shape
detailed_summary: Huck acknowledges the gravity of his thoughts and his declaration but stands by them.
He dismisses any further ideas about reforming his character.
He decides to revert to 'wickedness,' which he feels is more in his nature due to his upbringing, unlike the path of societal righteousness.
His immediate plan is to once again steal Jim out of slavery.
He resolves that if he can conceive of any more 'wicked' actions, he will undertake those as well, fully committing to his decision to defy societal norms for Jim's sake.
He begins to meticulously plan Jim's rescue, considering various strategies.
Eventually, he settles on a plan that he finds suitable.
He identifies a wooded island further down the river.
Once darkness falls, he quietly moves the raft to this island and conceals it.
He sleeps through the night, awakens before daylight, has breakfast, and changes into his better set of clothes ('store clothes').
He gathers some other belongings into a bundle, takes the canoe, and paddles towards the shore.

He lands the canoe at a spot he estimates is below Phelps's farm, hides his bundle in the woods, and then carefully sinks the canoe by filling it with water and rocks, ensuring he can retrieve it later from its location near a small steam sawmill.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was awful thoughts and awful words, but they was said.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I landed below where I judged was Phelps’s place, and hid my bundle in the woods, and then filled up the canoe with water, and loaded rocks into her and sunk her where I could find her again when I wanted her, about a quarter of a mile below a little steam sawmill that was on the bank.

events.text_segment:
It was awful thoughts and awful words, but they was said. And I let them stay said; and never thought no more about reforming. I shoved the whole thing out of my head, and said I would take up wickedness again, which was in my line, being brung up to it, and the other warn’t. And for a starter I would go to work and steal Jim out of slavery again; and if I could think up anything worse, I would do that, too; because as long as I was in, and in for good, I might as well go the whole hog.

events.title: Confrontation with the Duke and a Fabricated Tale
detailed_summary: Huck begins walking up the road from the river.
He passes a sawmill with a sign identifying it as 'Phelps’s Sawmill.'
Further on, as he approaches some farmhouses, he observes his surroundings carefully but sees no one, despite it being well into daylight.
This doesn't concern him, as his plan involves approaching the Phelps place from the direction of the village, not directly from where he landed.
He takes a quick look around and continues towards the town.
The first person he encounters in the village is the duke.
The duke is occupied with posting bills for a three-night run of the 'Royal Nonesuch' performance, reminiscent of their previous scam.
Huck is upon him before he can avoid the encounter.
The duke expresses astonishment at seeing Huck and then, with a somewhat pleased and eager tone, asks about the raft's whereabouts and if it's in a safe place.
Huck cleverly turns the question back on the duke, stating that he was about to ask the same thing.
The duke's joyful expression fades, and he questions Huck's reason for asking.
Huck then launches into an elaborate, fabricated story to explain his presence and the raft's supposed disappearance.
He claims that after seeing the king intoxicated in the tavern, he decided to wander around town to pass the time while waiting for the king to sober up.
He alleges that a man offered him ten cents to help row a skiff across the river and back to fetch a sheep.
According to Huck's tale, the sheep proved too strong, broke free, and led them on a chase all over the countryside until dark.
He claims that when he finally returned to where the raft had been hidden, it was gone.

Huck feigns distress, stating he concluded that the duke and king must have encountered trouble and had to leave, taking 'his' slave, Jim, with them, leaving him stranded, penniless, and alone in a strange place.

The duke then explains his version: the king had made a 'trade' (implying Jim for money) and received forty dollars. However, by the time they found the king in the tavern, loafers had won all his money except what he'd spent on whiskey. When they later discovered the raft was gone, they assumed Huck had stolen it and deserted them.
The duke demands the ten cents Huck mentioned from the supposed sheep-fetching job.

events.text_segment:
Then I struck up the road, and when I passed the mill I see a sign on it, “Phelps’s Sawmill,” and when I come to the farm-houses, two or three hundred yards further along, I kept my eyes peeled, but didn’t see nobody around, though it was good daylight now. But I didn’t mind, because I didn’t want to see nobody just yet—I only wanted to get the lay of the land. According to my plan, I was going to turn up there from the village, not from below. So I just took a look, and shoved along, straight for town. Well, the very first man I see when I got there was the duke. He was sticking up a bill for the Royal Nonesuch—three-night performance—like that other time. They had the cheek, them frauds! I was right on him before I could shirk. He looked astonished, and says:
“Hel-lo! Where’d you come from?” Then he says, kind of glad and eager, “Where’s the raft?—got her in a good place?”
I says:
“Why, that’s just what I was going to ask your grace.”
Then he didn’t look so joyful, and says:
“What was your idea for asking me?” he says.
“Well,” I says, “when I see the king in that doggery yesterday I says to myself, we can’t get him home for hours, till he’s soberer; so I went a-loafing around town to put in the time and wait. A man up and offered me ten cents to help him pull a skiff over the river and back to fetch a sheep, and so I went along; but when we was dragging him to the boat, and the man left me a-holt of the rope and went behind him to shove him along, he was too strong for me and jerked loose and run, and we after him. We didn’t have no dog, and so we had to chase him all over the country till we tired him out. We never got him till dark; then we fetched him over, and I started down for the raft. When I got there and see it was gone, I says to myself, ‘they’ve got into trouble and had to leave; and they’ve took my nigger, which is the only nigger I’ve got in the world, and now I’m in a strange country, and ain’t got no property no more, nor nothing, and no way to make my living;’ so I set down and cried. I slept in the woods all night. But what did become of the raft, then?—and Jim—poor Jim!”
“Blamed if I know—that is, what’s become of the raft. That old fool had made a trade and got forty dollars, and when we found him in the doggery the loafers had matched half-dollars with him and got every cent but what he’d spent for whisky; and when I got him home late last night and found the raft gone, we said, ‘That little rascal has stole our raft and shook us, and run off down the river.’”
“I wouldn’t shake my nigger, would I?—the only nigger I had in the world, and the only property.”
“We never thought of that. Fact is, I reckon we’d come to consider him our nigger; yes, we did consider him so—goodness knows we had trouble enough for him. So when we see the raft was gone and we flat broke, there warn’t anything for it but to try the Royal Nonesuch another shake. And I’ve pegged along ever since, dry as a powder-horn. Where’s that ten cents? Give it here.”

events.title: The Duke's Misdirection and Huck's Feigned Compliance
detailed_summary: Although Huck has money, he gives the duke only ten cents, pleading that it is all he possesses and that he is starving, hoping the duke will buy food and share.
The duke remains silent initially, but then suddenly confronts Huck, questioning whether Jim would inform on them, threatening to skin Jim if he did.
Huck deflects by asking how Jim could 'blow' on them if he has supposedly run off.
The duke then reveals the truth: the king sold Jim and kept all the money, which is now gone.
Huck feigns tears and distress, exclaiming that Jim was 'his' slave and therefore the money was rightfully his.
The duke dismisses Huck's supposed sorrow and eyes him with suspicion, questioning if Huck himself might betray them, his expression turning ugly.
Huck continues to whimper, insisting he doesn't want to betray anyone and is only focused on finding 'his nigger.'

The duke appears somewhat troubled by Huck's display and, after some thought, proposes a deal: they will be in town for three days, and if Huck promises not to betray them or allow Jim to do so, the duke will reveal Jim's location.
Huck readily agrees.
The duke begins to tell Huck the truth, starting with 'A farmer by the name of Silas Ph—' but then hesitates, reconsiders, and decides to lie to get Huck out of the way for the three days.
He falsely informs Huck that Jim was sold to Abram G. Foster, who supposedly lives forty miles away in the country, on the road to Lafayette.
Huck pretends to accept this, stating he can walk the distance in three days and will start that very afternoon.
The duke, however, insists Huck leave immediately and maintain silence about their conversation en route, a directive that perfectly suits Huck's own hidden agenda to be free to pursue his real plan.

I had considerable money, so I give him ten cents, but begged him to spend it for something to eat, and give me some, because it was all the money I had, and I hadn’t had nothing to eat since yesterday. He never said nothing. The next minute he whirls on me and says:
“Do you reckon that nigger would blow on us? We’d skin him if he done that!”
“How can he blow? Hain’t he run off?”
“No! That old fool sold him, and never divided with me, and the money’s gone.”
“Sold him?” I says, and begun to cry; “why, he was my nigger, and that was my money. Where is he?—I want my nigger.”
“Well, you can’t get your nigger, that’s all—so dry up your blubbering. Looky here—do you think you’d venture to blow on us? Blamed if I think I’d trust you. Why, if you was to blow on us—”
He stopped, but I never see the duke look so ugly out of his eyes before. I went on a-whimpering, and says:
“I don’t want to blow on nobody; and I ain’t got no time to blow, nohow. I got to turn out and find my nigger.”
He looked kinder bothered, and stood there with his bills fluttering on his arm, thinking, and wrinkling up his forehead. At last he says:
“I’ll tell you something. We got to be here three days. If you’ll promise you won’t blow, and won’t let the nigger blow, I’ll tell you where to find him.”
So I promised, and he says:
“A farmer by the name of Silas Ph—” and then he stopped. You see, he started to tell me the truth; but when he stopped that way, and begun to study and think again, I reckoned he was changing his mind. And so he was. He wouldn’t trust me; he wanted to make sure of having me out of the way the whole three days. So pretty soon he says:
“The man that bought him is named Abram Foster—Abram G. Foster—and he lives forty mile back here in the country, on the road to Lafayette.”
“All right,” I says, “I can walk it in three days. And I’ll start this very afternoon.”
“No you wont, you’ll start now; and don’t you lose any time about it, neither, nor do any gabbling by the way. Just keep a tight tongue in your head and move right along, and then you won’t get into trouble with us, d’ye hear?”
That was the order I wanted, and that was the one I played for. I wanted to be left free to work my plans.
“So clear out,” he says; “and you can tell Mr. Foster whatever you want to. Maybe you can get him to believe that Jim is your nigger—some idiots don’t require documents—leastways I’ve heard there’s such down South here. And when you tell him the handbill and the reward’s bogus, maybe he’ll believe you when you explain to him what the idea was for getting ’em out. Go ’long now, and tell him anything you want to; but mind you don’t work your jaw any between here and there.”

events.title: Strategic Retreat and Renewed Focus on Rescuing Jim
detailed_summary: Complying with the duke's directive, Huck departs and heads towards the back country, as instructed.
He mockingly suggests Huck can tell the fictional Mr. Foster anything, even try to convince him Jim is Huck's slave or that the reward handbill is bogus.
Huck senses that the duke is watching him as he leaves, but feels confident he can eventually evade this scrutiny.
He continues in the feigned direction for about a mile before stopping.
Once out of sight, he discreetly changes course, doubling back through the woods towards the actual location of Phelps's farm.
He believes it is crucial to begin his plan to rescue Jim without delay, partly to ensure Jim doesn't inadvertently reveal any information about the duke and king.
Huck is resolute in his desire to be completely free of the two con men, having had his fill of their company and deceit.

events.title: Arrival at Phelps' Plantation and Pervasive Loneliness
detailed_summary: The narrator arrives at a place that feels still, hot, and sunshiny, like a Sunday, with the farm workers away in the fields.
The faint droning of insects in the air contributes to a profound sense of loneliness, making it seem as if everyone has died.
A gentle breeze rustling the leaves evokes a mournful sensation, as if ancestral spirits are whispering directly about him.
This atmosphere generally makes a person wish they were also dead and free from it all.
Phelps' place is described as a typical small, one-horse cotton plantation.

A detailed description of the plantation's layout is provided: a rail-fenced yard, a log stile, sparse grass, a large double log-house for the white family with whitewashed mud chinking, a separate log kitchen connected by a covered passage, a smoke-house, three small log slave cabins, a solitary hut near the back fence, various outbuildings, an ash-hopper for soap making, a bench with a water bucket by the kitchen, and sleeping hounds.
The yard also contains a few shade trees, currant and gooseberry bushes, and beyond the fence, a garden, a watermelon patch, cotton fields, and finally, the woods.
The narrator enters the property by climbing over a back stile near the ash-hopper and heads towards the kitchen.
As he approaches, he hears the dim, wailing hum of a spinning wheel, which he identifies as the most lonesome sound in the world, reinforcing his earlier wish to be dead.

When I got there it was all still and Sunday-like, and hot and sunshiny; the hands was gone to the fields; and there was them kind of faint dronings of bugs and flies in the air that makes it seem so lonesome and like everybody’s dead and gone; and if a breeze fans along and quivers the leaves it makes you feel mournful, because you feel like it’s spirits whispering—spirits that’s been dead ever so many years—and you always think they’re talking about you. As a general thing it makes a body wish he was dead, too, and done with it all.
Phelps’ was one of these little one-horse cotton plantations, and they all look alike. A rail fence round a two-acre yard; a stile made out of logs sawed off and up-ended in steps, like barrels of a different length, to climb over the fence with, and for the women to stand on when they are going to jump on to a horse; some sickly grass-patches in the big yard, but mostly it was bare and smooth, like an old hat with the nap rubbed off; big double log-house for the white folks—hewed logs, with the chinks stopped up with mud or mortar, and these mud-stripes been whitewashed some time or another; round-log kitchen, with a big broad, open but roofed passage joining it to the house; log smoke-house back of the kitchen; three little log nigger-cabins in a row t’other side the smoke-house; one little hut all by itself away down against the back fence, and some outbuildings down a piece the other side; ash-hopper and big kettle to bile soap in by the little hut; bench by the kitchen door, with bucket of water and a gourd; hound asleep there in the sun; more hounds asleep round about; about three shade trees away off in a corner; some currant bushes and gooseberry bushes in one place by the fence; outside of the fence a garden and a watermelon patch; then the cotton fields begins, and after the fields the woods.
I went around and clumb over the back stile by the ash-hopper, and started for the kitchen. When I got a little ways I heard the dim hum of a spinning-wheel wailing along up and sinking along down again; and then I knowed for certain I wished I was dead—for that is the lonesomest sound in the whole world.

events.title: An Unexpected Welcome: Mistaken for Tom
characters: Lize's daughter (referred to as "little nigger girl")
Lize's two sons (referred to as "two little nigger boys")
Aunt Sally Phelps (referred to as "white woman")
Aunt Sally's children (referred to as "little white children")
detailed_summary: The narrator proceeds without a set plan, relying on Providence to guide his words, a strategy he has found effective in the past.
As he walks, he is suddenly surrounded by a large group of barking hounds, about fifteen of them, with more joining in.
He remains still and faces the dogs.
A Black woman, Lize, emerges from the kitchen with a rolling-pin, scolding and striking the dogs to drive them away.
After being dispersed, some of the hounds return, wagging their tails and acting friendly towards the narrator, who reflects that hounds are generally harmless.
Lize's three young children, dressed only in tow-linen shirts, cling to her gown and peek shyly at the narrator.
A white woman, around forty-five or fifty years old, bareheaded and holding a spinning-stick, runs out from the main house, followed by her own young children who exhibit similar shy behavior.
This woman, Aunt Sally Phelps, is smiling broadly and exclaims with apparent recognition, as if she has been expecting him.
The narrator instinctively confirms with a "Yes'm."
Aunt Sally enthusiastically embraces him, shakes his hands repeatedly, and tears well up in her eyes, expressing her profound joy at his arrival.
She comments that he doesn't resemble his mother as much as she anticipated but declares it doesn't matter because she is so glad to see him.
She affectionately tells her children that this is their cousin Tom and instructs them to greet him.

events.text_segment:
I went right along, not fixing up any particular plan, but just trusting to Providence to put the right words in my mouth when the time come; for I’d noticed that Providence always did put the right words in my mouth if I left it alone.
When I got half-way, first one hound and then another got up and went for me, and of course I stopped and faced them, and kept still. And such another powwow as they made! In a quarter of a minute I was a kind of a hub of a wheel, as you may say—spokes made out of dogs—circle of fifteen of them packed together around me, with their necks and noses stretched up towards me, a-barking and howling; and more a-coming; you could see them sailing over fences and around corners from everywheres.
A nigger woman come tearing out of the kitchen with a rolling-pin in her hand, singing out, “Begone you Tige! you Spot! begone sah!” and she fetched first one and then another of them a clip and sent them howling, and then the rest followed; and the next second half of them come back, wagging their tails around me, and making friends with me. There ain’t no harm in a hound, nohow.
And behind the woman comes a little nigger girl and two little nigger boys without anything on but tow-linen shirts, and they hung on to their mother’s gown, and peeped out from behind her at me, bashful, the way they always do. And here comes the white woman running from the house, about forty-five or fifty year old, bareheaded, and her spinning-stick in her hand; and behind her comes her little white children, acting the same way the little niggers was doing. She was smiling all over so she could hardly stand—and says:
“It’s you, at last!—ain’t it?”
I out with a “Yes’m” before I thought.
She grabbed me and hugged me tight; and then gripped me by both hands and shook and shook; and the tears come in her eyes, and run down over; and she couldn’t seem to hug and shake enough, and kept saying, “You don’t look as much like your mother as I reckoned you would; but law sakes, I don’t care for that, I’m so glad to see you! Dear, dear, it does seem like I could eat you up! Children, it’s your cousin Tom!—tell him howdy.”

events.title: Weaving Lies: Huck Navigates Aunt Sally's Questions
detailed_summary: Aunt Sally's children remain shy, hiding behind her and putting their fingers in their mouths.
Aunt Sally instructs Lize to quickly prepare a hot breakfast for the narrator, whom she believes to be Tom.
The narrator claims he has already eaten breakfast on the steamboat.
Aunt Sally then leads him by the hand into the house, with the children following.
Inside, she has him sit down and sits opposite him on a low stool, holding both his hands, expressing how eagerly she has anticipated this meeting for many years.
She mentions they had been expecting him for a couple of days and asks about the cause of his delay, suggesting his boat might have run aground.
The narrator begins to confirm, saying "Yes'm—she—".
Aunt Sally gently corrects him, telling him to call her "Aunt Sally," and then asks where the boat grounded.
Uncertain whether the boat was supposed to be traveling up or down the river, the narrator relies on his intuition, guessing it was coming upstream from the direction of New Orleans.
Lacking knowledge of specific sandbars in that area, he improvises and claims the delay wasn't due to grounding but because they "blowed out a cylinder-head."
Aunt Sally expresses concern, asking if anyone was injured.
The narrator replies, "No'm. Killed a nigger."

Aunt Sally considers this fortunate, remarking that sometimes "people do get hurt." She recounts a past incident where her husband, Uncle Silas, was on a boat, the Lally Rook, that blew a cylinder-head, crippling a man who later died from mortification after an amputation. She adds that the man was a Baptist.

She informs the narrator that Uncle Silas has been going to town daily to meet him and had left for town again just an hour prior, expecting him back shortly. She asks if he encountered Uncle Silas on the road.

The narrator denies meeting anyone, explaining that the boat landed at daylight, and he spent time exploring the town and countryside to pass the time before arriving at the plantation via the back way.
Aunt Sally then inquires about his baggage.
The narrator claims he gave it to nobody.
She expresses alarm that it will be stolen.
He reassures her, saying he believes it won't be stolen from where he hid it.
She then questions how he managed to get breakfast so early on the boat.
Feeling the situation is precarious, he invents another story, stating that the captain saw him and invited him to eat with the officers in the texas (officers' quarters) before he went ashore.

events.text_segment:
But they ducked their heads, and put their fingers in their mouths, and hid behind her. So she run on:
“Lize, hurry up and get him a hot breakfast right away—or did you get your breakfast on the boat?”
I said I had got it on the boat. So then she started for the house, leading me by the hand, and the children tagging after. When we got there she set me down in a split-bottomed chair, and set herself down on a little low stool in front of me, holding both of my hands, and says:
“Now I can have a good look at you; and, laws-a-me, I’ve been hungry for it a many and a many a time, all these long years, and it’s come at last! We been expecting you a couple of days and more. What kep’ you?—boat get aground?”
“Yes’m—she—”
“Don’t say yes’m—say Aunt Sally. Where’d she get aground?”
I didn’t rightly know what to say, because I didn’t know whether the boat would be coming up the river or down. But I go a good deal on instinct; and my instinct said she would be coming up—from down towards Orleans. That didn’t help me much, though; for I didn’t know the names of bars down that way. I see I’d got to invent a bar, or forget the name of the one we got aground on—or—Now I struck an idea, and fetched it out:
“It warn’t the grounding—that didn’t keep us back but a little. We blowed out a cylinder-head.”
“Good gracious! anybody hurt?”
“No’m. Killed a nigger.”
“Well, it’s lucky; because sometimes people do get hurt. Two years ago last Christmas your uncle Silas was coming up from Newrleans on the old Lally Rook, and she blowed out a cylinder-head and crippled a man. And I think he died afterwards. He was a Baptist. Your uncle Silas knowed a family in Baton Rouge that knowed his people very well. Yes, I remember now, he did die. Mortification set in, and they had to amputate him. But it didn’t save him. Yes, it was mortification—that was it. He turned blue all over, and died in the hope of a glorious resurrection. They say he was a sight to look at. Your uncle’s been up to the town every day to fetch you. And he’s gone again, not more’n an hour ago; he’ll be back any minute now. You must a met him on the road, didn’t you?—oldish man, with a—”
“No, I didn’t see nobody, Aunt Sally. The boat landed just at daylight, and I left my baggage on the wharf-boat and went looking around the town and out a piece in the country, to put in the time and not get here too soon; and so I come down the back way.”
“Who’d you give the baggage to?”
“Nobody.”
“Why, child, it’ll be stole!”
“Not where I hid it I reckon it won’t,” I says.
“How’d you get your breakfast so early on the boat?”
It was kinder thin ice, but I says:
“The captain see me standing around, and told me I better have something to eat before I went ashore; so he took me in the texas to the officers’ lunch, and give me all I wanted.”

events.title: Mounting Pressure and a Surprise Hiding Spot
detailed_summary: The narrator grows increasingly agitated and finds it hard to concentrate, constantly thinking about the children and wishing for an opportunity to discreetly ask them who he is supposed to be.
However, Mrs. Phelps (Aunt Sally) talks so incessantly that he gets no chance.
His anxiety peaks when she suddenly announces she wants to hear all about "Sis" and the rest of the family, asking him to tell her everything.
The narrator feels utterly trapped, realizing that Providence, which he usually relies on, has failed him in this instance.
He concludes that he has no option left but to risk telling the truth.
Just as he opens his mouth to confess, Mrs. Phelps urgently grabs him and pulls him behind the bed.
She explains that her husband is approaching and she intends to play a practical joke on him, instructing the narrator and the children to remain hidden and silent.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I was getting so uneasy I couldn’t listen good.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Children, don’t you say a word.”

events.text_segment:
I was getting so uneasy I couldn’t listen good. I had my mind on the children all the time; I wanted to get them out to one side and pump them a little, and find out who I was. But I couldn’t get no show, Mrs. Phelps kept it up and run on so. Pretty soon she made the cold chills streak all down my back, because she says:
“But here we’re a-running on this way, and you hain’t told me a word about Sis, nor any of them. Now I’ll rest my works a little, and you start up yourn; just tell me everything—tell me all about ’m all every one of ’m; and how they are, and what they’re doing, and what they told you to tell me; and every last thing you can think of.”
Well, I see I was up a stump—and up it good. Providence had stood by me this fur all right, but I was hard and tight aground now. I see it warn’t a bit of use to try to go ahead—I’d got to throw up my hand. So I says to myself, here’s another place where I got to resk the truth. I opened my mouth to begin; but she grabbed me and hustled me in behind the bed, and says:
“Here he comes! Stick your head down lower—there, that’ll do; you can’t be seen now. Don’t you let on you’re here. I’ll play a joke on him. Children, don’t you say a word.”

events.title: The Prank Unfolds: Uncle Silas's Concern and the Grand Reveal
detailed_summary: The narrator recognizes his predicament but understands there's nothing to do but stay still and mentally prepare for whatever consequences might follow.
He catches a fleeting glimpse of an older gentleman, Uncle Silas, entering the room just before the bed obstructs his view.
Mrs. Phelps immediately jumps up and asks her husband if "he" (meaning Tom) has arrived.
Uncle Silas responds that he has not.
Mrs. Phelps feigns immense surprise and distress, wondering aloud what could have happened to him.
Uncle Silas confesses he has no idea and admits the situation is making him extremely uneasy.

I had just one little glimpse of the old gentleman when he come in; then the bed hid him. Mrs. Phelps she jumps for him, and says:
“Has he come?”
“No,” says her husband.
“Good-ness gracious!” she says, “what in the warld can have become of him?”
“I can’t imagine,” says the old gentleman; “and I must say it makes me dreadful uneasy.”
“Uneasy!” she says; “I’m ready to go distracted! He must a come; and you’ve missed him along the road. I know it’s so—something tells me so.”
“Why, Sally, I couldn’t miss him along the road—you know that.”
“But oh, dear, dear, what will Sis say! He must a come! You must a missed him. He—”
“Oh, don’t distress me any more’n I’m already distressed. I don’t know what in the world to make of it. I’m at my wit’s end, and I don’t mind acknowledging ’t I’m right down scared. But there’s no hope that he’s come; for he couldn’t come and me miss him. Sally, it’s terrible—just terrible—something’s happened to the boat, sure!”

He sprung to the window at the head of the bed, and that give Mrs. Phelps the chance she wanted. The old gentleman stared, and says:
“Why, who’s that?”
“Who do you reckon ’t is?”
“I hain’t no idea. Who is it?”
“It’s Tom Sawyer!”

events.title: Identity Confirmed: Huck's Relief and Elaborate Lies
detailed_summary: The narrator is so profoundly relieved to learn his mistaken identity is Tom Sawyer that he feels he almost collapsed.
Before he has much time to process, Uncle Silas grabs his hand and shakes it vigorously and continuously.

Both Mr. and Mrs. Phelps then eagerly start firing questions at him about Sid, Mary, and the other members of the Sawyer family.
The narrator reflects that his own joy at finally discovering "who he was" (in this mistaken identity) was even greater than the Phelpses' happiness; it felt like a rebirth.

For the next two hours, they remained intensely focused on him, and by the time his jaw was tired from talking, he had told them more fabricated stories about his supposed family—the Sawyer family—than could possibly be true for any six actual Sawyer families.
He also elaborates on his invented steamboat problem, explaining that they had blown out a cylinder-head at the mouth of the White River, and it took three days to repair it.
This explanation was perfectly acceptable and effective because the Phelpses had no reason to doubt that such a repair would take three days.
He muses to himself that if he had claimed it was a "bolthead" instead of a cylinder-head, it would have been equally convincing.

But if they was joyful, it warn’t nothing to what I was; for it was like being born again, I was so glad to find out who I was. Well, they froze to me for two hours; and at last, when my chin was so tired it couldn’t hardly go any more, I had told them more about my family—I mean the Sawyer family—than ever happened to any six Sawyer families. And I explained all about how we blowed out a cylinder-head at the mouth of White River, and it took us three days to fix it. Which was all right, and worked first-rate; because they didn’t know but what it would take three days to fix it. If I’d a called it a bolthead it would a done just as well.

events.title: A New Complication and a Plan
detailed_summary: The narrator begins to feel a mixture of emotions: one part of him is quite comfortable with the ease of impersonating Tom Sawyer, but another part is becoming increasingly uncomfortable.
His ease is maintained until he hears the distinct sound of a steamboat coughing its way down the river.
This sound immediately sparks a new fear: what if the real Tom Sawyer is aboard that boat?
He worries that Tom might arrive unexpectedly and call out the narrator's real name before he has a chance to signal Tom to remain quiet and play along.
The narrator decides he cannot allow this to happen, as it would ruin everything.
He resolves that he must go up the road to intercept Tom.
To create an excuse for his departure, he tells the Phelpses that he intends to go to town to retrieve his baggage.
Uncle Silas offers to accompany him.
However, the narrator declines the offer, asserting that he can manage the horse by himself and would prefer that Uncle Silas not go to any trouble on his account.

The narrator explains he was never murdered but faked it, inviting Tom to feel him as proof.

So I started for town in the wagon, and when I was half-way I see a wagon coming, and sure enough it was Tom Sawyer, and I stopped and waited till he come along. I says “Hold on!” and it stopped alongside, and his mouth opened up like a trunk, and stayed so; and he swallowed two or three times like a person that’s got a dry throat, and then says:
“I hain’t ever done you no harm. You know that. So, then, what you want to come back and ha’nt me for?”
I says:
“I hain’t come back—I hain’t been gone.”
When he heard my voice it righted him up some, but he warn’t quite satisfied yet. He says:
“Don’t you play nothing on me, because I wouldn’t on you. Honest injun now, you ain’t a ghost?”
“Honest injun, I ain’t,” I says.
“Well—I—I—well, that ought to settle it, of course; but I can’t somehow seem to understand it no way. Looky here, warn’t you ever murdered at all?”
“No. I warn’t ever murdered at all—I played it on them. You come in here and feel of me if you don’t believe me.”
So he done it; and it satisfied him; and he was that glad to see me again he didn’t know what to do.

events.title: A Secret Revealed and an Astonishing Alliance
detailed_summary: Tom is immediately curious about the narrator's adventure and its mysterious nature.
The narrator postpones the full story, instead explaining his current difficult situation and asking for Tom's advice.
Tom thinks for a moment and proposes a plan: the narrator should take Tom's trunk, pretend it's his own, and return to the house slowly, while Tom will arrive later, feigning unfamiliarity.
The narrator then confides in Tom about a deeply personal secret: he is attempting to help an enslaved man named Jim, formerly belonging to Miss Watson, escape slavery.
Before Tom can respond, the narrator anticipates Tom's disapproval, acknowledging the act as 'dirty, low-down business' but stating his determination and asking for Tom's silence.
Tom's eyes light up, and he surprisingly declares, 'I’ll help you steal him!'

The narrator is completely taken aback by Tom's statement, finding it the most astonishing thing he's ever heard and admitting Tom's standing in his eyes diminished significantly, struggling to believe Tom would become a 'nigger stealer'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And he wanted to know all about it right off, because it was a grand adventure, and mysterious, and so it hit him where he lived.

events.text_segment:
And he wanted to know all about it right off, because it was a grand adventure, and mysterious, and so it hit him where he lived. But I said, leave it alone till by-and-by; and told his driver to wait, and we drove off a little piece, and I told him the kind of a fix I was in, and what did he reckon we better do? He said, let him alone a minute, and don’t disturb him. So he thought and thought, and pretty soon he says:
“It’s all right; I’ve got it. Take my trunk in your wagon, and let on it’s your’n; and you turn back and fool along slow, so as to get to the house about the time you ought to; and I’ll go towards town a piece, and take a fresh start, and get there a quarter or a half an hour after you; and you needn’t let on to know me at first.”
I says:
“All right; but wait a minute. There’s one more thing—a thing that nobody don’t know but me. And that is, there’s a nigger here that I’m a-trying to steal out of slavery, and his name is Jim—old Miss Watson’s Jim.”
He says:
“What! Why, Jim is—”
He stopped and went to studying. I says:
“I know what you’ll say. You’ll say it’s dirty, low-down business; but what if it is? I’m low down; and I’m a-going to steal him, and I want you keep mum and not let on. Will you?”
His eye lit up, and he says:
“I’ll help you steal him!”
Well, I let go all holts then, like I was shot. It was the most astonishing speech I ever heard—and I’m bound to say Tom Sawyer fell considerable in my estimation. Only I couldn’t believe it. Tom Sawyer a nigger stealer!

events.title: Plan Set in Motion and an Unexpectedly Swift Return

The old gentleman at the door marvels at the mare's speed, commenting on her lack of sweat and saying he wouldn't sell her for a hundred dollars, a significant increase from his previous valuation.

The narrator reflects that this was all the old gentleman said, describing him as the most innocent and best soul, a farmer who was also a preacher and had built a small church and schoolhouse at his own expense, never charging for his services, a common type in the South.

events.text_segment:
“Oh, shucks!” I says; “you’re joking.”
“I ain’t joking, either.”
“Well, then,” I says, “joking or no joking, if you hear anything said about a runaway nigger, don’t forget to remember that you don’t know nothing about him, and I don’t know nothing about him.”
Then we took the trunk and put it in my wagon, and he drove off his way and I drove mine. But of course I forgot all about driving slow on accounts of being glad and full of thinking; so I got home a heap too quick for that length of a trip. The old gentleman was at the door, and he says:
“Why, this is wonderful! Whoever would a thought it was in that mare to do it? I wish we’d a timed her. And she hain’t sweated a hair—not a hair. It’s wonderful. Why, I wouldn’t take a hundred dollars for that horse now—I wouldn’t, honest; and yet I’d a sold her for fifteen before, and thought ’twas all she was worth.”
That’s all he said. He was the innocentest, best old soul I ever see. But it warn’t surprising; because he warn’t only just a farmer, he was a preacher, too, and had a little one-horse log church down back of the plantation, which he built it himself at his own expense, for a church and schoolhouse, and never charged nothing for his preaching, and it was worth it, too. There was plenty other farmer-preachers like that, and done the same way, down South.

events.title: Tom Sawyer's Theatrical Arrival as a Stranger
detailed_summary: Approximately thirty minutes later, Tom Sawyer's wagon arrives.
Aunt Sally sees it from the window, assumes it's a stranger, and instructs a child, Jimmy, to tell Lize to set an extra plate for dinner.
The entire household rushes to the front door, as visitors are a rare and exciting occurrence.
Tom, dressed in his 'store clothes' and relishing the audience, approaches the house with a confident and stylish demeanor.
He removes his hat gracefully and inquires if he has arrived at Mr. Archibald Nichols's residence.
The old gentleman (Uncle Silas) informs him that Nichols's place is three miles further and invites Tom inside.
Tom glances back, notes his driver is gone, and initially declines the invitation, stating he will walk.
Both Uncle Silas and Aunt Sally insist he stay, citing Southern hospitality and the fact that a plate is already being set for him.
Tom graciously accepts their invitation, enters, and introduces himself as William Thompson from Hicksville, Ohio, with a bow.

events.text_segment:
In about half an hour Tom’s wagon drove up to the front stile, and Aunt Sally she see it through the window, because it was only about fifty yards, and says:
“Why, there’s somebody come! I wonder who ’tis? Why, I do believe it’s a stranger. Jimmy” (that’s one of the children) “run and tell Lize to put on another plate for dinner.”
Everybody made a rush for the front door, because, of course, a stranger don’t come every year, and so he lays over the yaller-fever, for interest, when he does come. Tom was over the stile and starting for the house; the wagon was spinning up the road for the village, and we was all bunched in the front door. Tom had his store clothes on, and an audience—and that was always nuts for Tom Sawyer. In them circumstances it warn’t no trouble to him to throw in an amount of style that was suitable. He warn’t a boy to meeky along up that yard like a sheep; no, he come ca’m and important, like the ram. When he got a-front of us he lifts his hat ever so gracious and dainty, like it was the lid of a box that had butterflies asleep in it and he didn’t want to disturb them, and says:
“Mr. Archibald Nichols, I presume?”
“No, my boy,” says the old gentleman, “I’m sorry to say ’t your driver has deceived you; Nichols’s place is down a matter of three mile more. Come in, come in.”
Tom he took a look back over his shoulder, and says, “Too late—he’s out of sight.”
“Yes, he’s gone, my son, and you must come in and eat your dinner with us; and then we’ll hitch up and take you down to Nichols’s.”
“Oh, I can’t make you so much trouble; I couldn’t think of it. I’ll walk—I don’t mind the distance.”
“But we won’t let you walk—it wouldn’t be Southern hospitality to do it. Come right in.”
“Oh, do,” says Aunt Sally; “it ain’t a bit of trouble to us, not a bit in the world. You must stay. It’s a long, dusty three mile, and we can’t let you walk. And, besides, I’ve already told ’em to put on another plate when I see you coming; so you mustn’t disappoint us. Come right in and make yourself at home.”
So Tom he thanked them very hearty and handsome, and let himself be persuaded, and come in; and when he was in he said he was a stranger from Hicksville, Ohio, and his name was William Thompson—and he made another bow.
